Influencer marketing is red-hot right now. Whether you realize it or not, a material percentage of your Instagram feed today is probably content posted by people getting paid….a lot. It’s not unheard of for the platform’s most popular accounts to get paid over $100,000 per post, and major brands collectively are spending an estimated $255 million per month on sponsored posts on Instagram alone.
Why will brands pay this much? Because it works. But for the most part influencer marketing is still only being used by big brands, because the infrastructure just isn’t there yet to let the smaller guys participate.
Meet Dovetale, an influencer marketing platform built for the masses. The company is one of the first to graduate from Expa Labs, an offshoot of Expa, the New York and San Francisco-based startup studio founded by Uber co-founder Garrett Camp in 2014.
Dovetale’s platform lets brands and agencies do four main things: discover, manage, measure and pay influencers for branded content. Essentially they want to provide a self-service platform that consolidates the manual steps brands typically have to take in order to find and work with an influencer.
Discover is exactly what it sounds like – the tool lets you specify parameters like follower count, audience location and demographic so you can find influencers whose posts will be seen by the exact demographic you want to advertise to. Combined these parameters will let you do something like say I need a personal trainer who has 20,000 followers who are mostly under 21, and live in the U.S. Previously brands and agencies would have to search manually through databases of influencers – Dovetale wants to make it as easy as a Google search.
Within Discover also a cool feature called recommendations that lets you upload an image you like, and Dovetale will use image recognition and machine learning to crawl the web looking for other influencers who post content like the kind you uploaded – even if they aren’t already in Dovetale’s database of influencers.
Measure is how the startup shows brands how their posts are performing. After specifying which posts were sponsored by you, Dovetale will tell you how many times it was liked, commented on, etc – so you can track and graph engagement over time and compare it between posts.
Lastly, Manage and Pay are designed to help brands manage influencers during and after campaigns. You can see a list of all the influencers you work with, what their current “reach” is, and even distribute a one-time payment for a campaign. Dovetale uses Stripe and charges 2.5% on all transfers, and is even working to provide all influencers with a 1099 tax form so you don’t have to worry about it.
Dovetale charges brands and agencies monthly for use of the entire platform, with three plans costing $199, $499, or $999 per month. The only differentiator is that the least expensive option doesn’t include demographic analytics (so you’d have to manually choose which influencers you think best fit your audience). $199 tier also only includes 25 monthly “recommendations”, which is the processing-heavy image recognition that searches for influencers outside of Dovetale’s database.
While $199 may seem like a lot, it’s important to understand that this monthly fee essentially lets a small brand work with influencers across every social platform – something that used to require an advertising agency or big in-house marketing team to accomplish. Now anyone from an Etsy jewelry shop to a new coffee shop in Brooklyn can get access to high-quality influencers that will work to drive audiences to their brand. This feature makes it easy for brands to discover their perfect match in a matter of minutes without having to search manually through databases of influencers. Additionally, there is a cool feature called recommendations that lets users upload an image they like, and Dovetale will use image recognition and machine learning to crawl the web looking for other influencers who post content like the kind uploaded, even if they aren't already in Dovetale's database of influencers. With Discover, Dovetale wants to provide a self-service platform that consolidates the manual steps brands typically have to take in order to find and work with an influencer.

real.content: What are the advantages and disadvantages of working from home versus working in an office setting?

Advantages of working from home:
1. Flexibility- enables you to manage your own schedule, work when you are most productive, and balance work with other responsibilities.
2. Commute time savings- saves money and time spent in transit to and from work.
3. Saving expenses- eliminates expenses related to commuting, work clothes, and meals.
4. Better work-life balance- can lead to better physical and emotional health, and allows for more time with family.
5. Increased productivity- with no distractions, people are able to focus on their work.

Disadvantages of working from home:
1. Social isolation- the lack of social interaction that one gets in an office environment can lead to feelings of loneliness and disconnection.
2. Distractions- working from home can be difficult due to the presence of children, pets, or household tasks and activities.
3. Difficulty separating work and personal life- can lead to working longer hours than necessary.
4. Reduced team collaboration- can lead to reduced innovation and limited learning opportunities.
5. Need of resources- you need to have a proper set up with a desk, computer, internet connection, etc.

Advantages of working in an office setting:
1. Social interactions- enables employees to communicate, share ideas and opinions.
2. Physical boundaries between work and home- difficult to work from home for some people as they get distracted, thus, working from an office setting keeps boundaries between work and personal life.
3. Increased learning opportunities- office provides an environment to learn from colleagues.
4. Reduced feelings of loneliness- office environment elevates the mood, keeps employees motivated.
5. Structured workday- a set schedule, work hours, provide a routine.

Disadvantages of working in an office setting:
1. Commute time- travelling to and from work can be time consuming.
2. Distractions- office environments can be noisy and can lead to lack of focus or productivity.
3. Work-life balance- long hours spent in the office can lead to a work-life imbalance and can lead to reduced physical and emotional health.
4. Reduced flexibility- Employees may be limited in terms of their work schedule and work location.
5. Expenses- additional expenses such as commuting, parking fees, and meals can add up.

real.content: Write a fictional short story (500-1000 words) that explores the journey of a character who undergoes a difficult experience and ultimately learns an important lesson. The story should include dialogue, vivid imagery, and characterization to effectively convey the lesson the character learns. Additionally, the story should have a clear structure and theme that ties everything together.

As a young girl growing up in rural Utah, Madison always had a love for the outdoors. She spent countless hours exploring the nearby mountains and forests with her father, learning about the beauty and fragility of nature. But nothing could prepare her for the journey she was about to embark on.

It started on a warm summer day, when Madison and her friend Sarah set out on a hike through a nearby canyon. They wanted to see if they could find a waterfall rumored to be hidden deep within the rocky cliffs. As they climbed higher and higher, the trail grew more treacherous, and the girls began to feel the strain of the journey.

But they pushed on, determined to see the waterfall. As they neared the top of the canyon, they could hear the sound of rushing water growing louder and louder. And then, suddenly, they were there – standing before a magnificent cascade of water, tumbling down from high above.

Madison and Sarah were awestruck, mesmerized by the beauty of the moment. But as they lingered near the waterfall, they began to realize that they had made a mistake. They hadn't brought enough water or food for the long hike back down. And as the day wore on, they grew more and more exhausted.

As the sun started to set, Madison and Sarah realized that they were lost, hopelessly wandering through the unfamiliar wilderness. They were hungry, thirsty, and scared, and each passing minute felt like an eternity. They fought to stay calm, but the situation seemed impossible.

It wasn't until they stumbled upon a small campsite that they started to feel some hope. An older couple was camping there, and they took the girls under their wing, giving them food, water, and shelter for the night.

As they huddled around the campfire, Madison felt a sense of gratitude that she had never felt before. She had always been adventurous and free-spirited, but now she realized just how precious life really was. She saw how easily things could go wrong, how quickly the world could turn against you.

Over the next few days, Madison and Sarah gradually made their way back to civilization. They were safe now, but the experience had changed them both forever. Madison started to appreciate the world in a whole new way – the trees, the rivers, the stars in the sky. Everything felt more vivid and alive, as if the world had been reborn.

It wasn't until later, as she reflected on the experience, that Madison realized the most important lesson she had learned. She had always been so focused on herself – her adventures, her experiences, her own ambition. But now she saw the value of community, of relying on others, of sharing the challenges and joys of the world. She still loved to explore, but now she saw it as a way to connect with others, to share the beauty and majesty of the world with those around her.

And as she looked back on that long, difficult journey through the wilderness, Madison felt a sense of pride and accomplishment. She had faced one of the greatest challenges of her life, and emerged on the other side with a new perspective, a new appreciation for the world around her. She knew that there would be many more adventures to come, and many more lessons to learn. But she was ready for whatever life had in store.

real.content: What types of data formats and architectures does Cray support for data storage and processing?

Cray supports a variety of data formats and architectures for data storage and processing, including:

1. Structured data formats: Cray supports structured data formats like JSON, XML, and CSV, which are used for tabular data storage and retrieval.

2. Unstructured data formats: Cray also supports unstructured data formats like text, image, audio, and video files, which are used for storing data sets that do not have a defined data structure.

3. Relational databases: Cray supports several relational databases, including Oracle, MySQL, and PostgreSQL, which are used for storing and retrieving structured data.

4. NoSQL databases: Cray also supports NoSQL databases like MongoDB and Cassandra, which are used for storing and retrieving unstructured and semi-structured data.

5. Distributed file systems: Cray supports distributed file systems like Hadoop Distributed File System (HDFS) and GlusterFS, which provide scalable storage for big data.

6. Cloud storage: Cray supports cloud storage solutions like Amazon S3 and Azure Blob Storage, which provide scalable object storage for large-scale data sets.

7. Parallel file systems: Cray supports parallel file systems like Lustre and GPFS, which can manage large amounts of data across distributed computing resources.

I had a great life once. A loving wife, a good job, and a happy family. But now, everything has gone wrong. The bottle has taken over my life, and I don't know how to stop. It all started after I lost my job. I got drunk to numb the pain, but soon enough, drinking became my only coping mechanism. 

At first, I didn't realize how much I was drinking. It was just one bottle of beer, and then two, and then three. Before I knew it, I was drinking day and night. I would drink alone, in the dark, where no one could see me. My wife knew, though. She tried to stop me, tried to talk me out of it, but I wouldn't listen. I thought I could handle it, that I was in control. But I wasn't. 

Every day was a struggle to stay sober. I would wake up, hungover and miserable, and swear that today would be different. But then the cravings would hit, and I would find myself reaching for the bottle. The evenings were the worst. That's when my mind started to race, and I couldn't think straight. My wife would beg me not to drink, but I just couldn't help myself. The alcohol had taken over, and I was powerless against it. 

My relationships suffered because of my addiction. My wife couldn't take it anymore and left me. My kids were ashamed of me and hardly spoke to me. My friends had all given up on me. I was alone, with nothing but my bottle to keep me company. 

My health was deteriorating, too. I felt sick all the time, and my hands shook uncontrollably. I couldn't even hold a glass without spilling it. My mind was foggy, and I couldn't remember anything. It was like I was living in a daze, a never-ending nightmare. 

But then, one day, I hit rock bottom. I woke up in the gutter, with no memory of how I got there. That was the wake-up call I needed. I knew I had to stop drinking before it killed me. I checked myself into rehab, and it was the hardest thing I've ever done. 

The first few days were hell. I felt like I was being torn apart from the inside out. But gradually, things started to get better. I started to talk to the people around me, and I discovered I wasn't alone. We all had our struggles and demons to face. 

It wasn't easy, but I did it. I made it through rehab, and I've been sober for a year now. My relationships are slowly improving, and I've even started dating again. I have a new job, and I'm feeling better than ever. But most importantly, I've learned to forgive myself. I know I can never undo what I did, but I can make amends and move forward. The bottle may have taken over my life, but I refuse to let it define me.

If you said money, Ding! Ding! Ding! How else do you think salespeople got the reputation of being coin operated?
Even though money is important, it’s not the only important thing to your team members.
Don’t get me wrong; you must pay your people fairly if you expect to have a happy sales team. But the way you pay shouldn’t be just in dollars. Another form of currency our employees will gladly accept is appreciation.
Even if paying more money sounds like a logical plan, giving raises simply to make employees happier isn’t a sustainable strategy. If you plan to be in business next year, you may want to consider the more cost effective way to increase your employees’ happiness.
Tell one of their peers about something they do well (behind their back). Trust me, it will get back to them.
Catch them doing something right and point it out.
Brag on them in front of their customer. Nothing boosts the confidence of a salesperson (and a customer) than a leader who validates the ability of their people.
Write a (handwritten) letter of appreciation to your employee and their significant other. It’s one thing to tell your significant other that you’re appreciated at work. It’s a whole other thing to get tangible proof in the mail.
Tell them you appreciate their hard work and let them come in late every once in a while.
Tell them about a strength you see in them. Be specific and tell them about something you saw them do, or heard them say, as evidence of their strength.
What if they get recruited and leave? Well, what if they feel unappreciated and stay?
None of these tips are hard, but they are difficult to do consistently. When we as leaders show appreciation to those around us, we get happier employees who create happier customers who create healthy, thriving businesses.

Include options that cater to a range of dietary requirements and preferences such as vegan or gluten-free, and provide tips on how to prepare, present and serve the snacks in an appealing and appetising manner. Ensure that the snacks are easy to eat on-the-go and can be enjoyed by both adults and children, and suggest alternatives to traditional high-calorie or high-fat party snacks.

1. Fresh fruit skewers: Thread sliced fresh fruit onto skewers for a colorful and convenient snack. You can use a wide range of fruits such as pineapple, grapes, kiwi, berries, and watermelon.

2. Veggie sticks with hummus: Dice up carrots, celery, and cucumbers and serve with a side of hummus for a healthy and filling snack.

3. Roasted chickpeas: They are a popular crunchy and tasty snack that's easy to make in advance. You can season them with a variety of spices like chili powder, cumin, garlic powder, paprika.

4. Trail mix: Mix together a combination of nuts, seeds, dried fruits and chocolate chips for a healthy and filling snack. You can customize the mix as per individual preference.

5. Avocado toast: Avocado and whole-grain bread are perfect for a satisfying snack. Spread mashed avocado on toasted bread and top with sliced tomatoes or a sprinkle of sea salt.

6. Raw veggies with cashew dip: Make a vegan dip with cashews, black pepper, and lemon juice. Serve with raw veggies like carrots, cucumber, and celery.

7. Sweet potato fries: Baked sweet potato fries are a healthy and low-calorie alternative to traditional potato chips. You can add flavor by seasoning with garlic, onion powder, and paprika.

8. Popcorn: Popcorn is a classic snack that can be made in advance and jazzed up with seasonings like cinnamon, cumin, or nutritional yeast.

9. Rice cakes with toppings: Brown rice cakes can be topped with almond butter, sliced bananas and honey or hummus, sliced cucumbers and a sprinkle of sea salt.

10. Greek yogurt with fruit: Mix Greek yogurt with sliced strawberries or blueberries for a protein-packed snack.

11. Sliced apple with almond butter: Sliced apples make a tasty treat when you add a dollop of almond butter.

12. Edamame: Steamed edamame pods sprinkled with sea salt makes a high-protein snack.

13. Baked pita chips with tzatziki dip: Bake pita chips and serve with tzatziki dip made with Greek yogurt, garlic, and cucumber.

14. Cucumber bites: Slice cucumbers and top with feta cheese and sliced olives for a Mediterranean-inspired appetizer.

15. Fruit smoothies: Blend different fruits with yogurt or almond milk to make a refreshing and nutritious beverage.

Presentation tips:

• Display the snacks in a tiered tray to make them more visually appealing.
• Serve the dips and spreads in a colorful array of bowls.
• Place snack bowls at different heights throughout the room to keep people coming back for more.
• Use mini skewers for fruits and blend together colors like red and green grapes.
• Use mason jars to serve smoothies; add a straw and a fun umbrella to get the party started.

2. Streamlined Maintenance and Repairs: AR technology enables technicians to easily and quickly identify and diagnose issues with machines and equipment. With real-time information and the ability to visualize procedures, technicians can repair or maintain equipment more efficiently and reduce machine downtime.

3. Improved Assembly Line Efficiency: AR technology can be used to overlay virtual assembly instructions and guidelines onto real-world equipment, reducing the time taken to assemble parts and minimizing errors.

4. Quality Control: AR technology can assist in quality control by providing real-time feedback on product quality, allowing workers to catch and correct errors before they become problems.

5. Cost Savings: By reducing errors, improving efficiency, and streamlining maintenance and repairs, AR technology can help companies save significant costs in various aspects of production.

Overall, AR technology has the potential to transform manufacturing by improving worker efficiency, reducing errors, and enhancing overall productivity. Its application in various industries will continue to evolve as the technology advances and more use cases emerge.

The program should provide insights on customer satisfaction and complaints, overall hotel ratings, and staff performance. Here's a Python program that can extract hotel reviews from TripAdvisor using web scraping techniques.

### Step 1: Setup

Before starting with the code, you will need to install the necessary libraries - BeautifulSoup, requests and pandas. You can install them using pip: 

```
pip install beautifulsoup4
pip install requests
pip install pandas
```


### Step 2: Retrieve HTML Content

We will scrap TripAdvisor website to get the reviews. To do this, we make an HTTP request to the reviews page and get the HTML content.

```python
import requests
from bs4 import BeautifulSoup

url = 'https://www.tripadvisor.com/Hotel_Review-g45963-d675833-Reviews-The_Kitano_Hotel_New_York-New_York_City_New_York.html'
response = requests.get(url)

soup = BeautifulSoup(response.text, 'html.parser')
```

### Step 3: Extract Review Content

We can use BeautifulSoup to extract the review content from the HTML content we retrieved earlier. In this example, we are interested in the ratings, the review text and the date.

```python
reviews = soup.find_all('div', {'data-hook': 'review'})

for item in reviews:
    rating = item.find('span', {'class': 'ui_bubble_rating'})['class'][1].split('_')[-1]
    review_text = item.find('p', {'class': 'partial_entry'}).text
    review_date = item.find('span', {'class': 'ratingDate'})['title']
    
    print(f'Rating: {rating} \nReview: {review_text} \nDate: {review_date}\n')
```

### Step 4: Store the Review Content in a Dataframe

After extracting the reviews, we can store the data in a dataframe for further processing. We create a dictionary to hold the data and then convert it into a dataframe.

```python
import pandas as pd

reviews_list = []

for item in reviews:
    rating = item.find('span', {'class': 'ui_bubble_rating'})['class'][1].split('_')[-1]
    review_text = item.find('p', {'class': 'partial_entry'}).text
    review_date = item.find('span', {'class': 'ratingDate'})['title']
    
    reviews_dict = {'Rating': int(rating), 'Review': review_text, 'Date': review_date}
    reviews_list.append(reviews_dict)

reviews_df = pd.DataFrame(reviews_list)
```

### Step 5: Analyzing the review content

Once we have the reviews stored in a dataframe, we can use different Python libraries to analyze the data. For example, we can use matplotlib to create a histogram that shows the distribution of the ratings.

```python
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

plt.hist(reviews_df['Rating'])
plt.title('Hotel Ratings')
plt.xlabel('Rating')
plt.ylabel('Number of Reviews')
plt.show()
```

We can also use natural language processing libraries like NLTK to analyze the review text.

```python
import nltk
from nltk.sentiment.vader import SentimentIntensityAnalyzer

nltk.download('vader_lexicon')

sia = SentimentIntensityAnalyzer()

reviews_df['Sentiment'] = reviews_df['Review'].apply(lambda x: sia.polarity_scores(x)['compound'])
```

The above code will add a new column called Sentiment to the dataframe which contains the sentiment score for each review.

### Conclusion

In this way, we can easily extract and analyze hotel reviews using Python. We can enhance the program to scrape reviews from multiple hotel websites and combine them to get a comprehensive view of the customer satisfaction and complaints. The program can be used by hotel management to improve customer satisfaction and staff performance.

FROM customers
WHERE address LIKE '%XYZ%'
ORDER BY last_name, first_name ASC;

This SQL query selects all columns (`*`) from the `customers` table where the `address` column contains the string 'XYZ'. The `WHERE` clause filters for records in the table where the `address` contains the substring 'XYZ' (case insensitive). Finally, the `ORDER BY` clause sorts the result set by `last_name` in ascending order ('first_name' in descending order) while keeping `first_name` in place for sorting purposes. This results in a sorted list of customers who have addresses containing 'XYZ', with their names sorted alphabetically by last name. **Note:** Make sure to replace `'XYZ'` with the actual string you want to search for in the `address` field. real.content: Research and write a report on the future of renewable energy in South America.

Introduction

Renewable energy is regarded as one of the crucial elements that can aid in mitigating climate change globally. In South America, the need for sustainable energy sources is on the rise due to several factors, including population growth, rapid urbanization, and increased energy demand. This report provides an overview of the future of renewable energy in South America, highlighting the current state of renewable energy in the region, the potential for growth, and the challenges that must be addressed to realize a sustainable future.

Current State of Renewable Energy in South America

South America is rich in renewable resources, particularly hydroelectricity. In 2019, hydroelectricity contributed over 60% of the total electricity generation in the region, with Non-hydro renewables contributing less than 10%. However, the overall renewable energy capacity is low compared to Europe and North America, indicating that there is untapped potential for renewable energy development in the region.

According to the International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA), the total installed renewable energy capacity in South America was 56 GW in 2019, mainly driven by hydroelectricity. Brazil leads the way with the highest installed capacity of various renewable energy sources such as wind, biomass, and solar. Other countries such as Colombia, Chile, and Uruguay are making significant strides in developing renewable energy sources in their respective markets.

Potential for Growth

South America's potential to generate renewable energy is immense due to its vast landmass, diverse climate, and abundant natural resources. The region is home to some of the world's largest solar and wind energy resources, particularly in the Atacama Desert in Chile and the Brazilian Northeast. In addition, biomass and geothermal sources are available in countries such as Colombia, Peru, and Chile.

Several renewable energy projects are in the pipeline, with some already underway in the region. For instance, the Nine Mile hydroelectric complex in Peru and the Ituango hydropower plant in Colombia are expected to contribute significantly to the region's renewable energy capacity. Wind power projects have also been initiated in Brazil, Argentina, and Uruguay, with expected capacities of more than 1 GW.

Furthermore, numerous initiatives are being implemented to support renewable energy development in the region. For example, Chile aims to generate 70% of its energy from renewable sources by 2050, while Argentina has set a target of 20% of renewable energy in its national energy mix by the end of this year.

Challenges to Renewable Energy Development

Despite the potential for renewable energy development, the sector faces several challenges that must be overcome to achieve sustainable growth. One of the primary concerns is the lack of adequate infrastructure, particularly in remote areas, presenting challenges to connect to the grid. Additionally, the high costs of renewable energy technology and long payback periods are significant barriers to investment in the sector.

Furthermore, regulatory frameworks in some countries are not favorable to renewable energy, leading to a lack of incentives and long approval processes for project development. Weak transmission grids and low investment in renewable energy research are other issues that pose challenges to the sector's growth in some countries.

Conclusion

The future of renewable energy in South America is promising, with the potential for significant expansion due to the region's diverse renewable energy sources. However, the sector must address several challenges such as lack of infrastructure, high costs, and unfavorable regulatory frameworks. The region must adopt comprehensive policies and strategies that incentivize renewable energy investment, encourage research and development, and promote clean energy production. A collaborative approach between governments, policymakers, investors, and stakeholders in the private and public sector is critical to driving and achieving a sustainable future for South America.

real.content: Examine the impact of technology on the food industry.

The impact of technology on the food industry has been significant in recent years. Innovation and advancements in technology have changed how the food industry operates, from the production and manufacturing stage to the point of consumption.

1. Production and Manufacturing

In the production and manufacturing stage, technology has greatly improved efficiency and productivity. Automation through robots and machines has reduced the need for human labor and has made food production faster and cheaper. Technology has also improved the quality of products by enhancing the accuracy of processes such as measuring ingredients, temperatures, and times.

2. Logistics and Transport

Technology has made logistics and transport more efficient, effective, and faster. The use of sensors and tracking technology in vehicles and warehouses has helped to monitor food safety and quality, reducing the risk of contamination or damage. The development of refrigeration and storage technology has also aided in ensuring food safety and freshness.

3. Retail and Consumer Experience

Technology has transformed the way consumers interact with the food industry. The use of mobile apps and online platforms has allowed for easy ordering, payment, and delivery of food products. The development of digital signage, augmented reality, and virtual reality has also enhanced the consumer experience by providing immersive and engaging interactions with food products.

4. Sustainability and Food Security

Technology has played a critical role in addressing sustainability and food security concerns in the food industry. With the world population expected to continue to grow, technology has been used to increase the yield of crops, support precision agriculture, and reduce food waste. Additionally, technology has helped to create new plant-based alternatives to traditional animal-based products, addressing issues of resource depletion and animal welfare.

In conclusion, technology has positively impacted the food industry by improving efficiency, quality, safety, and sustainability, and enhancing the overall consumer experience.
